instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWR_GD: What is ALL_SYS_PWR_GD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS_PWR_GD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello,
this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is not turning on. It has an orange light in the charger and there is no visible damage on the board.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is not there because <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is also missing. I checked <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and i ge a 1V p-p clock signal on pin 12 (on my oszilloskop) so i think this is fine.
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. Here it gets a bit confusing for me. As far as i understand <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> is needed for the CPU/PCH to work. But this is created by <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. This needs a bunch S0 Rails to be created. But as <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing on this board it is not in a S0 state. So i am back to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> not beeing created.
Would be really great if somebode could give me a short explanation of how this works, what comes on first and help me fix this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: First thing to determine is if the board is power cycling. Check if <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is pulsing, best to do with scope. If not then check PPVRTC. Also check all rails for shorts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is straight 0V - even if i put the scope to 0.1 us/div. Same thing for <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>. There was indeed a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. I slowly injected voltage in there (starting at 0.9 V - 3.5 V were enough to feel something getting hot) and <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> got hot. I replced it. The short is gone now (0.377 V to GND in diode mode)  but still no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and still 0V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> without pulsing. Also PPVRTC is still not pulsing. I checked ll other rails for shorts and two of the readings are a little low i think. 

<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> (and the other ram rails are similar) = 0.09V to GND in diode mode. This may still be ok because its a small circuit with low voltage on it...
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0.031V to GND in diode mode. I think that is the problem.
should i inject voltage in there (up to max. 1.5 V) and see what gets hot? I am always careful if it comes to shorts on VCORE...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ..........Never mind

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: PPVRTC should be present. Check for short and replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> as that generates it. <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> probably got killed by connecting a shorted or damaged LCD cable. Inspect cable and connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I wanted to say, that PPVRTC is also straight and not pulsing. But it is present - straight 3,3 V. Sorry, my english is not the best. LCD cable and connector look fine and i get 0,38 V to GND in diode mode at pin 28, 29 and 30 (with the LCD cable plugged in).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present? PPBUS voltage? I suspect that there is some more history to this board, <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> does not "just" die like that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.341 V and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.61 V. The only thing the customer said is that it just stopped working... And the whole machine looks near perfekt (inside and outside...)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What are resistance to GND values on those 2 rails with low diode mode reading?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL>  : ~255 Ohm (multimeter counting up and down -+10 Ohm) 
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>           : <70 Ohm (multimeter slowly counting down)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That is within what I would call fine. At this point it could be anything and you really need to find some history. No way <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> just died, no way in hell. See if you can find any other shorted rails too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I contacted the customer today and he said, that he left the macbook copying some files to an external drove and as he came back it was dead... I checked all rails listed in the scematic and they are all not shorted as far as i can tell. Few of them have a readings of 0.13 V in diode mode to GND (others up to 0.6 V).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
The external drive is a hint. <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> is on 5V so I bet the 5V got hit with some spike though USB. Measure resistance to GND on all <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> S0 and compare to known good. It is not looking good though :(
Also ask if they are using China garbage charger as that is what usually causes weird current loops that kill machines like this, due to bad insulation from mains power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I am not sure if i did the right thing but i measured the resistances on all these rails. I attached a document where i compared it to a working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (as that is the closest equivalent working board i have) and i also added the components where i took the measurements. I hope that hepls but even if it did not help this time i have the readings to compare other <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards in the future to...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Not seeing anything that is worrying. Is <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: yes it is at pin 8 of the Bios chip 3.34 V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This is getting shitty. <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: yes... 3.38 V at <RESISTOR>R5185</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ugh :(. Is there any pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>? Check while connecting power, it may happen just once. Use a scope and set "one shot" mode to be able  to capture it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes, it is pulsing for a second but after that it is back to 0 V. I only have a CRT so i took a photo with my phone as good as i could. Hope that is good enought...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What is the time base and volts/div here? Check if <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is showing the same behavior too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That was at 50 mV/div and 5 us/div. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWR_GD</SIGNAL> shows a different behaviour. If i connect the adapter it just has a single pulse to ~3 V but it is so fast that i cant capture it. After that its back to 0 V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The 3V spike on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> would suggest the board tries to power on once. I still suspect a short on a rail or possible corrupt BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I measured the resistance of all rails and added the values to the table. The new values are blue. I added a picture. I will  try a new Bios chip today too and let you know if that changes something...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I also swapped the BIOS but still no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: having same issue waiting from some ones help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Make your own thread with measurements etc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Was the BIOS from an identical board and are you sure it has a good binary in it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The bios was from the same board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A). I have no idea how i can know if the binary is good?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You read it with programmer. The chips on some of the China boards are erased. If it was a donor that was not from China then it is probably fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I put the original Bios IC back on and read the china Bios with my progeammr and a new small PCB where i can solder these Bios ICs on. It is not empty and can be read without any errors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It may very well be a dead CPU then. I am out of ideas otherwise, sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No Title

No problem. Thank you for the outstanding help. Even if it it may be dead i could learn the troubleshooting process. 
In the mean time i got another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in (i could fix this one and it still works fine). So i took all resistance measurements again from this working board, added the values to my sheet and uploaded it here. Only <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> are noticable lower than the values from the working board. So maybe this could be the last chance for this board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have no explanation for this! No idea why <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> was missing. (this signal is really confusing to me) But i followed the lower resistance values (even if the diode mode readings were the same - i also dont really understand how that could be) and there are only three places where <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> meet. And only <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> makes sense here. So i replaced <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>. The diode mode readings did not change but the resistance readings came back up and - i could not belive it- the board turns on. So i dont know what to say at this ponit except thank you very much for your great help and patience.
You and this whole forum are amazing!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Wow, you got a very lucky fix on this one!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hi Duke!! I have same board with pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, Can you give me a hand? Thanks :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is ok, ppbus is ok,<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is pulsing ! PPVRTC is ok!

Sorry and let me know if i have to open new topic, and i will!! Sorry but this case is very very near to mine!!

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Make a new thread!
